p: All over history, microfinance has benefited both developing and developed countries (Khavul, 2010). Although microcredit projects have been popularised in the last decades in South Asia, microcredit has established ancient roots in Europe (Gatto, 2018; Seibel, 2013). Microfinance programmes do, indeed, benefit both the Global South and the Global North (Gatto et al., 2022; Spiegel, 2012). There is debate on the entity of microfinance beneficiaries – whether they are the poorest or not in a community (Koh et al., 2021; Pearlman, 2012). Regardless of this, there is consensus on the fact that microfinance can alleviate socioeconomic problems in any society – including poverty – and offer entrepreneurial opportunities, especially amongst the most vulnerable socioeconomic groups (Ranabahu and Tanima, 2021; Ullah and Khan, 2017).
